Ingredients:
Vegetable oil
Tomatoes, blended
Bell pepper, blended
Onions, diced (some for cooking, some for topping)
Tomato paste
Curry powder
Thyme
Ground pepper (to taste)
Meat stock (chicken or beef)
Seasoning cubes or salt (to taste)
Rice
Water
Butter
Chicken, fish, or other protein (for serving)
Procedures:
Heat some oil in a pot and cook the blended tomatoes, bell pepper, and part of the onions until very cooked. Remove from the pot and set aside to cool slightly.
In the same pot, add more oil and the diced onions. Cook until translucent.
Add the tomato paste to the onions and fry until the oil begins to separate from the paste.
Stir in the curry and thyme, cooking for a few minutes to release their flavors.
Add the previously cooked tomato and bell pepper mixture back into the pot. Mix well.
Pour in the meat stock and add ground pepper. Stir and let it come to a simmer.
Season with seasoning cubes or salt to taste.
Wash the rice under cold water and then add it to the pot. Stir to ensure the rice is well coated with the sauce.
Add enough water to cover the rice by about an inch.
Taste and adjust the seasoning as needed.
Place more diced onions on top of the rice, then cover the pot and let it cook on low heat.
When the rice is almost done, add a knob of butter and stir it through to melt and distribute evenly.
Continue cooking until the rice is completely done and fluffy.
Serve the Jollof Rice hot with your choice of chicken, fish, or another protein.

Ingredients:
Vegetable oil
1-2 Scotch bonnet peppers, grated (adjust to your spice preference)
1 large onion, finely chopped (more if desired, for added flavor)
1 teaspoon curry powder
1 teaspoon thyme
Salt to taste
Meat or chicken stock
2 cups rice, washed and drained
1 cup green peppers, chopped
1 cup carrots, chopped
1 cup peas (add last if using frozen)
Optional proteins like fried liver or cooked shrimp
1 cup canned sweet corn
1 cup canned red kidney beans (optional)
Procedures:
Prepare the Rice:
In a large pot, heat some oil over medium heat.
Sauté the grated Scotch bonnet briefly, then add half of the chopped onions along with the curry powder, thyme, and salt.
Pour in the meat or chicken stock and bring to a boil.
Add the rice, reduce heat to low, cover, and cook until the rice is tender. Add more onions towards the end of cooking if desired.
Cook the Vegetables and Proteins:
While the rice cooks, heat some oil in another pan.
Add carrots first as they take longer to cook, followed by green peppers and peas.
If using, add your choice of additional protein and sauté until well cooked.
Combine and Serve:
Once the rice and vegetables are cooked, combine them in a large pot or pan.
Stir in the canned vegetables like sweet corn and kidney beans if using.
Mix everything thoroughly but gently to avoid mashing the ingredients.
Adjust seasoning if needed and serve hot.

Ingredients:
4 cups bread flour
1 tbsp sugar
1 tsp salt
1 tbsp vegetable oil
2 tsps instant yeast
1¼ cups warm water
Water for boiling
1 tbsp baking soda
Procedures:
Mix flour, sugar, salt, and yeast. Add warm water and oil, and knead until smooth.
Let the dough rise until doubled. Punch down and divide into 8 pieces. Shape each into a bagel and let rest for 10 minutes.
Boil water with baking soda. Boil each bagel for 1 minute per side.
Bake at 425°F for about 20 minutes.

Ingredients:
2 cups all-purpose flour
1 tsp instant yeast
1 tsp sugar
½ tsp salt
⅓ cup warm water
¼ cup yogurt
2 tbsp melted butter
2 cloves garlic, minced
Procedures:
Combine flour, yeast, sugar, and salt. Mix in water, yogurt, and butter to form a dough. Knead until smooth.
Let it rise until doubled. Divide into balls and roll into ovals.
Cook in a hot skillet until bubbly, then flip. Brush with garlic butter.

Ingredients:
2¼ cups all-purpose flour
⅓ cup sugar
1 packet instant yeast
2 tbsp butter, melted
¼ cup milk, warm
2 eggs
Oil for frying
Sugar or glaze for coating
Procedures:
Mix flour, sugar, and yeast. Add milk, butter, and eggs, and knead until smooth.
Let it rise until doubled. Roll out dough and cut out donuts.
Fry in hot oil until golden. Coat with sugar or glaze.

Ingredients:
Sliced bread
Cooked chicken, sliced
Carrots, grated
Bell peppers, sliced
Mayonnaise
Mustard (optional)
Salt and pepper
Lettuce (optional)
Procedures:
Mix mayonnaise and mustard.
Spread on both slices of bread.
Layer lettuce, chicken, carrots, and bell peppers.
Season with salt and pepper.
Close with the second slice of bread.

Ingredients:
Fried/ baked potatoes
Mayonnaise
Carrots 
Cucumbers
Eggs
Procedures:
Mix mayonnaise,
Add potatoes,carrots , cucumbers, eggs and any other thing you would like to add to your salad.  Mix well and chill before serving.

Ingredients:
8 beaten eggs, large
1/2 cup of water, filtered
3 tbsp. of tomato paste, no salt added
1 pepper, scotch bonnet or habanero
1 cup of oil, cooking
1/2 chopped bell pepper, green
1/2 chopped bell pepper, red
1 chopped onion, large
Bouillon cube or salt, kosher, as desired
1/2 tbsp. of garlic, crushed
To garnish: 1 spring onion stalk
Procedures:
Makes 5 servings
Cooking + Prep Time: 20 minutes
Ingredients:

Instructions:
Heat oil in medium pan. Add garlic and onions. Sauté till the onions have
softened.
Add tomato paste to pan. Fry for three minutes and stir, so it won’t burn.
Add chopped peppers. Cook on low for 2 minutes more.
Add 1 cup of water to beaten eggs. Stir gradually into bubbly stew. Break
up eggs by continuously stirring. Serve.

Ingredients:
1 cup of coconut flakes, unsweetened
1/4 cup of sugar, superfine or caster
3 yolks from large eggs
1/2 cup of flour, self-rising
Procedures:
Makes 14 balls
Cooking + Prep Time: 40 minutes
Preheat oven to 350F.
In medium mixing bowl, combine egg yolks, coconut and sugar, forming
stiff dough. Form the dough in 1” balls. Roll balls in flour, coating them.
Place balls on cookie sheet with 2” between them.
Bake in 350F oven for 18-20 minutes, till golden. Serve.

Ingredients:
2 cups of rice, short grain – you can use jasmine rice if you like
1 tbsp. of yeast
1 tbsp. of sugar, granulated
1 tbsp. of oil, vegetable
1/2 tsp. of ginger, grated
Procedures:
Makes 2 servings
Cooking + Prep Time: 50 minutes + 6-8 hours sitting time
Soak 1 cup of rice in filtered water. Add 1/2 tbsp. of yeast. Allow to set for
6 to 8 hours.
Boil other rice cup. Mash it well, then set it aside.
Pour soaked rice in food processor. Add mashed rice. Blend till rice is
smooth.
Into blended mixture, add sugar and ginger. Add last tbsp. of yeast. Allow
to rise for 1/2 hour or so.
Grease a pan lightly. Add mixture. Brown on one side. Then, flip and brown
second side. Serve with your favorite syrup.

Ingredients: Yam(Preferred quantity)
Procedures:
Makes various # of servings
Cooking + Prep Time: 35 minutes
Peel yams using sharp knife. Don’t remove too much flesh.
Remove spoiled spots, discolored areas or bruised areas as you’re peeling.
Cut yams in large chunks. Immediately wash so they don’t become
discolored. Allow them to sit in cool water till you’re ready to use them.
Add yam chunks to med. pot with sufficient water to cover them. Season as
desired.
Boil yams till tender, then remove from the heat. Drain in colander. Reserve
some yam cooking water.
Pour pounded yams in food processor. Begin to blend, then change to
pulsing every 20 to 30 seconds, checking for smoothness. Add water as
needed till you have the texture you desire.
Wrap in parchment paper or cling wrap. Serve with soup of ypur choice

Ingredients:
1 & 3/4 cups plus 2 tbsp. of flour, all-purpose
1/3 cup of sugar, granulated
4 tbsp. of butter, salted
1/2 tsp. of nutmeg, ground
1 egg, large
1/4 cup of milk, evaporated
1/2 tsp. of baking powder
To deep fry: oil, olive
Procedures:
Makes 10 servings
Cooking + Prep Time: 55 minutes
Mix the dry ingredients in bowl. Set bowl aside.
Mix wet ingredients except butter in separate bowl. Set it aside.
Add the butter to dry mixture. Combine with fingers.
Pour in remainder of wet ingredients. Mix together till it forms a dough.
Wrap the dough in cling wrap. Allow to set on kitchen counter for five
minutes or so.
Unwrap the dough. Roll it out into 1/4” thickness. Cut dough into small
squares.
Place small squares in bowl. Sprinkle them with flour and shake it around
so they won’t be sticky.
Heat oil. Fry dough pieces till light gold in color. Remove and lay out on
layered paper towels. They will start out soft, but as they cook, they will
harden. Serve.

Ingredients:
1 to 2 lb. of meat, your choice of cow skin, tripe, stew beef or
oxtail
1 cup of fish, smoked
1 cup of onion, diced
1/2 cup of crayfish, ground
1 tbsp. of bouillon, chicken
3 cups of chopped kale, collard greens or spinach
1/4 to 1/3 cup of oil, palm
1 tbsp. of pepper flakes, red
1/2 cup of ogbono or pumpkin seeds, ground
Salt, kosher, as desired
Pepper, black, as desired
Procedures:
Makes various # of servings
Cooking + Prep Time: 1 hour & 20 minutes
In medium pan, boil the meat, seasoned as desired, for 30 to 60 minutes, till
tender. Add the smoked fish. Reserve three to 4 cups of meat stock.
Mix ground ogbono or pumpkin seeds with oil. Add to boiled meat pot,
then add scotch bonnet and crayfish. Bring to boil. Then, simmer and allow
to cook for 10 minutes minimum. Add bouillon, if desired.
Add additional stock water if needed, till you reach the thickness you
desire. Then, add spinach or other greens and cook for another two to three
minutes. Turn off heat. Serve hot with preferred swallow.

Ingredients:
1 cup flour
2 tbsp sugar
1 tbsp baking powder
½ tsp salt
1 cup milk
2 tbsp melted butter
1 egg
Procedures:
Mix dry ingredients. Whisk in milk, butter, and egg until smooth.
Pour batter onto a hot griddle and cook until bubbles form. Flip and cook until golden.

Ingredients:
3 ripe bananas, mashed
⅓ cup melted butter
1 tsp baking soda
Pinch of salt
¾ cup sugar
1 beaten egg
1 tsp vanilla extract
1½ cups all-purpose flour
Procedures:
Preheat oven to 350°F. Mix bananas and butter. Stir in baking soda and salt. Add sugar, egg, and vanilla, then flour.
Pour into a loaf pan and add toppings of your choice (nuts, coconuts , etc)and bake for about 1 hour.

Ingredients:
3¼ cups flour
1 cup warm water
1 packet yeast
3 tbsp sugar
1 beaten egg
3 tbsp butter, melted
1 tsp salt
Procedures:
Mix flour, sugar, yeast, and salt. Add water, egg, and butter. Knead until smooth.
Let rise until doubled. Divide into buns and let rise. Brush with egg wash.
Bake at 375°F for about 15 minutes.

Ingredients:
1 ripe avocado
Lemon juice
Salt and pepper
Eggs
Honey
Procedures:
Mash avocado with lemon juice, salt, and pepper.
Spread on toasted bread. Add egg cooked as desired(poached, boiled, fried) preferrably runny and Drizzle some honey and more pepper if you like spice

Ingredients:
Yam, peeled and cut into chunks
Vegetable stock or water, enough to cover the yam
Onions, chopped
Ground tomatoes
Bell pepper, chopped
Scotch bonnet pepper, chopped
Titus fish (Mackerel), cooked and chopped
Ponmo (Cow skin), cooked and chopped
Palm oil
Salt
Bouillon cubes
Ugwu leaves (Pumpkin leaves), chopped
Procedures:
Place the yam in a large pot and add enough vegetable stock or water cover it and let it cook. When it is partly cooked , Add the chopped onions, ground tomatoes, bell pepper, and scotch bonnet. In a seperate pot, cook your titus and ponmo and season to taste.
When the yam is tender Add the palm oil, choppedTitus fish and chopped ponmo.
Mash some of the yam lightly to thicken the porridge. Season with salt and bouillon cubes.
Add the ugwu leaves and simmer for another 5 minutes.When it is done , mash the yam to yoyr preferred texture .Serve hot.

Ingredients:
Oatmeal 
Milk 
Preferred topping (banabas, beries , strawberry )
Procedures:
In a small pot, bring water or milk to a boil.
Add the oats and a pinch of salt, then reduce heat to a simmer.
Cook, stirring occasionally, until the oats are soft and have absorbed the liquid, about 5 minutes.
Serve with your choice of toppings.

Ingredients:
Assorted meats (such as beef, goat, tripe, and intestines)
2 onions, chopped
Salt, to taste
Palm oil
Scotch bonnet peppers, chopped
Crayfish, ground
Water leaves (or substitute with spinach if unavailable)
Ugwu leaves (pumpkin leaves), chopped
Seasoning cubes or powder
Procedures:
Cook the assorted meats with one chopped onion and salt until tender.
Add palm oil and scotch bonnet peppers to the cooked meat and cook for about 10 minutes.
Add crayfish, the remaining onion, and seasoning. Cook for 5 minutes.
Stir in the water leaves, cook for 3 minutes, then add the ugwu leaves.
Adjust seasoning and simmer for another 5 minutes.
Serve hot with fufu or pounded yam.

Ingredients:
Beans
Water
Sodium bicarbonate
Palm oil
Seasoning (salt, stock cubes)
Procedures:
Cook peeled beans in water with sodium bicarbonate until very soft(disintegrating in water).
Strain, discarding solids, keeping the liquid.
Add palm oil and seasoning to the bean liquid.
Cook until creamy and well blended.

Ingredients:
2 cups chopped okra
1/2 kg assorted meats and fish
2 tablespoons palm oil
1 onion, sliced
2 tablespoons ground crayfish
1 teaspoon locust beans (iru)
Salt and pepper to taste
Procedures:
Cook the meats and fish with onions, salt, and pepper until tender, In a seperate pot cook the okra with Sodium bicarbonate.
Add palm oil, crayfish, and locust beans to the pot.
Add the okra and cook until the soup thickens.
Serve hot with eba or semo.

Ingredients:
1/2 kg goat meat/ meat of choice cut into chunks
2 tablespoons peppersoup spice mix
1 onion, chopped
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 liter water
Salt to taste
Chopped green onions for garnish
Procedures:
Combine meat, spices, onion, garlic, and water in a pot.
Bring to a boil and simmer until the meat is tender.
Season with salt and garnish with scallions.
Serve hot.

Ingredients:
2 cups rice
1 cup coconut milk
1 cup chicken or vegetable stock
1 onion, finely chopped
1 red bell pepper, diced
1 green bell pepper, diced
1/2 cup sweet corn
2 tablespoons coconut oil
Salt and black pepper to taste
Procedures:
In a pot, heat the coconut oil and sauté the onion until translucent.
Add the rice and stir for a few minutes until well coated with oil.
Pour in the coconut milk and stock, bring to a boil.
Reduce heat, cover, and simmer until rice is tender and liquid is absorbed.
Stir in bell peppers and sweet corn, adjust seasoning with salt and black pepper. Serve hot.

Ingredients:
Cooking oil: Vegetable 
Onions: 2-3, chopped (use in stages)
Grated pepper: Bell peppers or tomatoes
Rodo (Scotch bonnet pepper): Finely chopped
Curry powder
Thyme
Garlic: Minced
Stock: Goat meat, chicken, or fish stock
Meat or fish: Goat meat or fish, cooked and optionally cubed (both are optional)
Rice
Butter
Procedures:
Heat oil in a large pot, then sauté half the chopped onions until translucent.
Add grated pepper and rodo, cooking until softened.
Stir in curry powder, thyme, and minced garlic; cook until fragrant.
Pour in the stock (goat, chicken, or fish) and bring to a boil.
Add the rice, and if using, the pre-cooked meat or fish.
When the rice is nearly soft, add the remaining chopped onions; continue cooking until the rice is fully soft.
Just before serving, stir in a knob of butter for richness.
Serve the rice hot.

Ingredients:
2 ½ cups flour
1 cup sugar
½ cup butter
1 egg
1 tsp vanilla extract
½ tsp baking powder
Procedures:
Cream together butter and sugar until fluffy.
Beat in the egg and vanilla.
Gradually add the flour and baking powder. Mix into a stiff dough.
Shape the dough into balls and flatten on a baking sheet.
Bake at 180°C for 10-15 minutes or until golden.

Ingredients:
5 hard-boiled eggs
2 cups flour
½ cup sugar
½ cup butter
1 tsp baking powder
Water as needed
Oil for frying
Procedures:
Make a dough with flour, sugar, butter, baking powder, and enough water to form a smooth, pliable dough.
Divide the dough into 5 portions.
Wrap each portion around a hard-boiled egg, ensuring it is fully covered.
Deep fry in hot oil until golden brown.

Ingredients:
Ingredients for Filling:
500g minced meat
1 onion, chopped
2 carrots, diced
2 potatoes, diced
1 cup of water or broth
Salt and pepper to taste
Ingredients for Dough:
4 cups flour
1 cup margarine
1 egg (for glazing)
Cold water
Procedures:
For the filling: Cook the minced meat with onions, carrots, potatoes, water/broth, salt, and pepper until everything is tender.
For the dough: Mix flour and margarine to a breadcrumb texture, add water to form a dough.
Roll out dough, cut into rounds, place some filling in the center, fold, and seal edges.
Brush with beaten egg and bake at 180°C until golden.

Ingredients:
Sausage meat
Puff pastry sheets
1 egg (for glazing)
Procedures:
Roll out the puff pastry.
Place sausage meat along one edge.
Roll up the pastry to enclose the sausage meat.
Cut into pieces, place on a baking sheet, brush with egg, and bake at 200°C until golden.

Ingredients:
2 cups of rice
½ cup palm oil
Locust beans (iru)
Smoked fish
1 onion, chopped
2 bell peppers, blended
Salt and pepper to taste
Procedures:
Wash and cook the rice until almost done.
In another pot, heat palm oil, add onions, blended peppers, locust beans, smoked fish, and cook for about 10 minutes.
Mix in the cooked rice, adjust seasoning, and serve.

Ingredients:
Potatoes, peeled and sliced
Salt
Oil for frying
Procedures:
Cut up potatoes to preferred shaped and dip in water 
Deep fry in hot oil until crispy and golden. Drain on paper towels.
Season potato slices with salt when hot 
Serve with peppered sauce or sauce of choice

Ingredients:
Yam, peeled and sliced
Salt
Oil for frying
Procedures:
Instructions:

Season yam slices with salt.
Deep fry in hot oil until crispy and golden. Drain on paper towels.

Ingredients:
2 cups beans
1 onion, chopped
1 bell pepper, blended
Palm oil
Salt and smoked fish
Procedures:
Cook beans with salt to taste and enough water until tender.
Add onions, blended pepper and palm oil 
Cook until the beans are soft and the flavors meld.

Ingredients:
2 cups black-eyed peas
Water
Ingredients for Sauce:

1 cup palm oil
1 onion, sliced
1 tbsp chili powder
Salt to taste
Procedures:
Cook the beans until very soft and mushy.
For the sauce, heat palm oil, fry the onions until very dark but not burnt, add chili powder and salt.
Pour the sauce over the beans and serve with bread.

Ingredients:
2 cups rice
Yeast
Sugar
Water
1/2 cup Cooked rice
Procedures:
Grind the rice with some cooked rice into a paste 
Mix the rice paste with yeast, sugar, and enough water to form a batter.
Allow to ferment for a few hours.
Cook in a special masa pan until golden and crispy.

Ingredients:
2 cups rice or maize flour
Water
Procedures:
Boil water in a pot.
Gradually add the flour while stirring until it forms a thick, smooth dough.(work fast to avoid lumps)
Cover and let cook for a few minutes. Serve with soup or stew.

Ingredients:
2 cups rice
1 cup dried beans
Dried millet leaves (for coloring)
Salt
Procedures:
Cook the beans with the millet leaves until tender.
Add rice and salt, and cook until both are done. Serve with shito and stew or with yaji and fried onions.

Ingredients:
2 bunches Ugwu leaves ( you can also use Spinach or Soko)
3 medium /2 big size bell peppers (Tatashe)
11/2scotch bonnet (Rodo)
1/2 cup Palm Oil
11/2 medium size red onions
Assorted meats of your choice (Shaki, Kpomo, cow leg, smoked turkey or beef are ideal)
Dried stockfish (Panla)
Smoked cat fish
1 tablespoon Locust beans (Iru)
1/2 cup raw/cooked prawns (Optional)
1/4 cup smoked prawns (Optional)
2 Knorr chicken cubes or any bullion cubes of your choosing.
3 tablespoons ground Crayfish
Salt to taste
Procedures:
First, get your core  ingredients ready. Efo Riro is a fast cooking dish, so you’ll need to be proactive.Now, season the meats, add sliced onions and boil on medium heat. Remember to boil the tougher meats first, then add the softer ones. Just before it’s fully cooked, add the Stockfish, boil till tender and set aside.
Wash your vegetables thoroughly with hot water to rid it of all traces of dirt, be careful not to in soak in hot water for too long so as to retain the nutrients. Slice or chop according to your preference and set aside.
Blend the scotch bonnets and bell peppers and an onion coarsely and set aside…
Into a large pot, add the palm oil, leave to heat up on medium heat for 2 minutes ….Then add onions, fry till fragrant.
Then add the locust beans, fry to release the flavour for another minute….
Now add the blended pepper and two Knorr cubes, let that fry for 15-20 minutes thereabouts or until the pepper dries out and the size reduces by almost half….The consistency should be thick as pictured below….
Add a bit of the meat stock/ chicken stock, if you haven’t got stock, just add water, be careful not to add too much. Just one cup should do.
Let it boil for 2-3 minutes to combine, then add the assorted meats, prawns, crayfish, stockfish and catfish.
Combine and taste, adjust seasoning if required. Leave to cook for a further 10 minutes.
Now add the washed vegetables, combine thoroughly…
Switch off the heat at this time, leave to simmer for a further 5 minutes with the residual heat and it’s ready.Efo Riro Serve with any “swallow” of your choice. Efo Riro is also prefect with white rice, boiled yam and plantain.

Ingredients:
2 cups of dried shredded cassava (Abacha)
1 cup of palm oil
2 tablespoons of ground crayfish
2 teaspoons of ground Ehu seeds (Calabash nutmeg)
Salt to taste
1 onion, sliced
Fresh green or red peppers, chopped
Ugba (fermented oil bean seeds), optional
1 tablespoon of potash water (nkanwu solution)
Garden eggs and garden egg leaves, sliced (optional)
Fish, boiled and flaked or dried fish
Boiled eggs, sliced (for garnishing)
Pomo (cow skin), cooked and diced (optional)
Procedures:
Soak the Abacha in cold water for about 10 minutes, then drain and set aside.
Dissolve the potash in a little water, strain, and mix with the palm oil in a large bowl until the color lightens.
Add the ground crayfish, ground Ehu, salt, and pepper to the oil mixture, and mix thoroughly.
Add the drained Abacha, sliced onions, chopped peppers, Ugba (if using), garden eggs, and leaves (if using), and mix well.
Adjust seasoning and mix again to ensure everything is well combined.
Garnish with flaked fish, diced pomo, and sliced boiled eggs.
Serve as a cold or room-temperature salad.

Ingredients:
1kg Assorted meats (Beef, Smoked Turkey, Goat meat, Shaki, Ponmo, Cow leg are ideal)

4 Bunches of Water leaves

3 Cups Okazi/ Afang leaves

2 Cooking Spoons Palm Oil

1-2 Pieces Smoked Fish

3 Pieces Stockfish

2 Cups Periwinkles with or without the Shells on

1-2 cooking spoons fresh ground Scotch Bonnet pepper

1 Cooking Spoon Crayfish Powder

2 Knorr Chicken Cubes, and Salt to taste

1 Maggi Crayfish
Procedures:
Boil the meats on high heat, starting with tougher meats first. Offals may be boiled separately if they are bloody. Add salt and Knorr Chicken Cubes and seasoning, onions are optional, I don’t use any. I gather onions aren’t needed when preparing authentic Afang soup.
When the meats are almost soft, add the Smoked fish and continue to boil till very soft…While the meats are cooking, get the leaves ready.

Slice and wash the Water leaves to remove all traces of dirt. Also wash and soak the Okazi/ Afang leaves in hot water for 2 minutes. This process will help soften the Afang leaves.Then transfer the Afang leaves into a blender, add a small amount of water, then blend to your preferred consistency. You may also Pound or grind the Afang leaves.Soak the smoked Catfish in hot water, clean to remove traces of dirt then shred and set aside…

When the meats are well cooked, you should end up with 1-2 Cups of Stock. To this, add the Crayfish, blended pepper, Smoked Prawns,  Smoked Fish, Maggi Crayfish and Periwinkles if you’re using any. Turn the heat down to medium. Leave to cook for 3-5. minutes….Soak the smoked Catfish in hot water, clean to remove traces of dirt then shred and set aside…

When the meats are well cooked, you should end up with 1-2 Cups of Stock. To this, add the Crayfish, blended pepper, Smoked Prawns,  Smoked Fish, Maggi Crayfish and Periwinkles if you’re using any. Turn the heat down to medium. Leave to cook for 3-5. minutes….Now, add the Palm oil, stir and combine, leave to cook for 3 minutes…Add the blended Okazi/ Afang leaves, stir and combine, leave to cook for 5 minutes or until the leaves are tender enough for you. Taste for seasoning at this time and adjust if necessary…Switch the heat off and let it simmer with the residual heat for another minute or two…. And it is ready 
Enjoy with any swallow of your choice…

Ingredients:
2 cups palm nut extract
500g assorted meats (beef, tripe, goat)
1 medium onion, chopped
2 tablespoons ground crayfish
2 teaspoons Banga spice (oburunbebe stick, iteji, rohojie)
Salt and pepper to taste
1 dried fish, cleaned
1 tablespoon of bitter leaves or scent leaves, chopped
Procedures:
Cook the assorted meats with onions and salt until tender.
Add the palm nut extract and enough water to form a medium consistency soup.
Add the Banga spices, ground crayfish, and dried fish.
Cook for about 30 minutes on medium heat.
Stir in the chopped leaves, adjust seasoning, and simmer for another 5 minutes.
Serve hot with starch or fufu.

Ingredients:
500g chicken gizzards, cleaned and cut into bite-sized pieces
2 ripe plantains, diced
1 onion, chopped
2 bell peppers, diced
2 tomatoes, chopped
1 scotch bonnet, finely chopped
3 tablespoons vegetable oil
Salt and pepper to taste
Procedures:
Boil the gizzards with a little salt until tender, then fry until golden.
Fry the diced plantains in another pan until golden and set aside.
In a pan, heat oil, sauté onions, tomatoes, bell peppers, and scotch bonnet until soft.
Add the fried gizzards to the sauce, then incorporate the fried plantains.
Cook together for a few minutes, season to taste, and serve.

Ingredients:
Ripe plantains
Ground pepper and salt (optional)
Procedures:
Preheat an outdoor grill.
Peel the plantains and slice if desired, or leave whole.
Sprinkle with pepper and salt (if using).
Place on the grill and cook, turning occasionally, until the plantains are cooked through and have char marks.
Serve hot.

Ingredients:
Overripe plantains
1 egg
Flour (as needed for binding)
Sugar (optional, to taste)
Salt to taste
Oil for frying
Procedures:
Mash the plantains until smooth. Mix in the egg, a bit of flour, sugar, and salt until you have a thick batter.
Heat oil in a deep fryer.
Spoon dollops of the batter into the hot oil and fry until golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve warm.

Ingredients:
Ingredients for Wrappers:
1 cup all-purpose flour
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/2 cup water (more if needed)
2 teaspoons oil
Ingredients for Filling:
1 cup shredded cabbage
1/2 cup julienned carrots
1/2 cup thinly sliced bell peppers
1/2 cup cooked chicken or shrimp (optional)
1 tablespoon soy sauce
Salt and pepper to taste
Oil for frying
Procedures:
Mix flour and salt in a bowl. Gradually add water and oil, mixing to form a smooth, thin batter.
Heat a non-stick pan lightly greased with oil over medium heat.
Pour a small amount of batter into the pan, swirling to spread it into a thin layer.
Cook until the edges start to peel away, then carefully remove the wrapper. Repeat with the remaining batter.
Instructions for Filling and Assembly:
Heat a small amount of oil in a pan. Sauté cabbage, carrots, and bell peppers until just tender. Add chicken or shrimp if using. Season with soy sauce, salt, and pepper.
Place a spoonful of filling on each wrapper. Fold in the sides and roll tightly.
Heat oil in a deep fryer or large pan. Fry the spring rolls until golden brown and crispy.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot.

Ingredients:
2 cups penne pasta
1 onion, sliced
1 bell pepper and  Rodo sliced
1 carrot
2 tablespoons olive oil
Seasoning Cubes 
Salt and pepper to taste
Tomato paste
Procedures:
In a pot of boiling water , add a general amount of salt and your penne pasta and cook till aldente 
Heat olive oil in a large skillet or wok Add rodo and fry till cooked 
Add onions, bell pepper, and carrots, stir-frying until they are crisp-tender.
Add the pre-boiled penne pasta and seasoning cubes. Stir-fry for a few minutes until the pasta is heated through and vegetables are mixed well.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot.

Ingredients:
2 cups spaghetti
1 onion, sliced
1 bell pepper and rodo  sliced
1 carrot
2 tablespoons olive oil
Seasoning cubes,
Salt and pepper to taste
Tomato paste
Procedures:
In a pot of boiling water , add a general amount of salt and your Spagetti and cook till aldente 
Heat olive oil in a large skillet or wok. Add rodo and fry till cooked 
Then add onions, bell pepper, carrots, and seasning stir-frying until they are crisp-tender.
Add the pre-boiled penne pasta and seasoning cubes. Stir-fry for a few minutes until the pasta is heated through and vegetables are mixed well.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot.

Ingredients:
4 potatoes, peeled and sliced
1 onion, sliced
1 bell pepper, sliced
2 tablespoons olive oil
Salt and pepper to taste
Optional: sausages or chicken bits
Procedures:
Boil the sliced potatoes until just tender, then drain.
In a large pan, heat the oil and fry the onions until translucent.
Add the boiled potatoes and bell pepper, and stir fry until golden and crisp.
Season with salt and pepper, and add sausages or bacon if using.
Serve hot.

Ingredients:
2 cups yam flour

 1/3 a cup of water

 Salt to taste 

Any good cooking Oil
Procedures:
Get a pot of water going on medium heat (you want this to start to boil when ready to steam your yam flour mix) 
Sieve your flour to get rid of any unwanted debris (the flour I used was milled in a public mill used of groundnuts, corn etc. so it’s inevitable that some of these residues may be in it) 
Pour the sieved yam flour into a big bowl and gradually add water in. You want to mix it thoroughly in circular motion aiming for the flour and water mixture to turn into small grains like couscous. Don’t be heavy on the water but if you are, you can adjust with flour. Be patient because this can take up to 10 minutes. To speed up the process, you can shake the bowl so be patient and crack on till you get that texture 
Get the second part of your steamer on the boiling water and pour the mixture in and cover it for 15 minutes, staring gentle after the first 10 minutes
After 15 minutes, take it off the fire and rinse in cold water to allow any unwanted particles that may still be in to come to the surface, and also to take any bitterness that yam can sometimes have. The water also helps to break any clumps that may have formed. You may have to wash it twice 
 Let it drain for a few minutes and then add 3 teaspoons of oil, salt to taste and mix 
 Get the mixture back into the steam pot/colander and back on the boiling pot of water 
To keep the steam in, you can put a clean kitchen cloth/ parchment paper over the pot before covering. After another 10 – 12 minutes, your wasawasa is ready to be taken off the fire and into a serving dish
Serve with shito and all the trimmings you want (spaghetti, cooked black eyed-beans, chopped lettuce/ cabbage, onions etc. and any protein choice!

Ingredients:
Cocoyam
Banana leaves
Salt
Onion, grated (optional)
Instructions:
Procedures:
Peel and grate the cocoyam.
Mix grated cocoyam with salt (and onion if using).
Wrap portions in banana leaves.
Steam until the cocoyam mixture is firm and cooked.
Serve warm with eforiro

Ingredients:
2 cups grated water yam
1 onion, chopped
2 tablespoons palm oil
Fish, cleaned and deboned
1 bell pepper, blended
Salt and bouillon cubes to taste
Procedures:
In a pot, heat palm oil and fry onions until translucent.
Add the blended bell pepper and cook for a few minutes.
Add water, bring to a boil, then stir in the grated water yam.
Add fish, season with salt and bouillon cubes.
Cook until the mixture thickens into a porridge.
Serve hot.

Ingredients:
2 cups peeled beans
1 onion, chopped
Salt to taste
Banana leaves or moi moi leaves or nylon
Procedures:
Blend the beans with onion and a little water to form a smooth paste.
Season with salt.
Wrap portions in leaves and steam for about 1-2 hours until set.
Serve with a spicy pepper sauce.

Ingredients:
4 large potatoes, peeled and cubed
1/4 cup milk
2 tablespoons butter
Salt and pepper to taste
Procedures:
Boil the potatoes until tender.
Drain and mash with milk and butter until smooth.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve warm.

Ingredients:
Beans
Red bell pepper
Rodo (Scotch bonnet pepper)
Onions
Salt
Oil for frying
Procedures:
Blend beans, red bell pepper, rodo, and onions into a smooth paste.
Whisk the paste till fluffy and lighter in color.
Heat oil in a deep pan.
Drop spoonfuls of the bean mixture into the hot oil.
Fry until golden brown and drain on paper towels.

Ingredients:
500g ground beef
1 onion, finely chopped
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 egg, beaten
1/2 cup breadcrumbs
Salt and pepper to taste
2 tablespoons olive oil
Procedures:
In a bowl, mix beef, onion, garlic, egg, breadcrumbs, salt, and pepper.
Form into balls.
Heat oil in a skillet and fry meatballs until browned and cooked through.
Serve hot with sauce or pasta.

Ingredients:
4 Big Bell Peppers (Tatashe)

2-3 Scotch Bonnet Peppers (Ata Rodo)

1.5 Onions

1 Cup Palm Oil

Assorted Meats (Boiled and Fried)

1 Cooking Spoon Locust Beans (Iru)

Smoked Fish (Shredded)

Stock fish (Shredded)

Ponmo 

Boiled Eggs

2 Knorr Chicken Cubes

Salt to taste
Procedures:
Blend the Bell Peppers, Scotch Bonner and 1 Onion coarsely, then set aside.

Pour the Palm oil into a saucepan, then place on medium heat. When the Oil heats up, add 1/2 chopped onions. Fry for 2 minutes..

After 2 minutes, add the Locust Beans. Fry for a further 2 minutes..Then add the Blended Pepper..Also add the Stock Cubes and Salt to taste.When the stew is boiling , add the ponmo.Fry for 20 minutes, making sure you stir from time to time to prevent burning..

After 20 minutes, the Oil would have settled well on the top of the Stew..Now, add the Shredded Fish, Meats and boiked eggs . Then leave it to cook on LOW heat then leave to fry for 30 minutes.
(You can fry for up to an hour. As long as you’ve got enough Palm oil and the heat is on low, you’ll be fine, just remember to stir occasionally…)

Ingredients:
4 green bell peppers
2 scotch bonnet peppers
1 medium onion
500g assorted meat (beef, liver, and tripe)
1 cup palm oil
1 tablespoon locust beans (iru)
2 bouillon cubes
Salt to taste
2 tablespoons ground crayfish
3 boiled eggs (optional)
Fried plantains (optional)
Procedures:
Blend the green bell peppers, scotch bonnet peppers, and half of the onion until smooth.
Heat the palm oil in a pot until it changes color to a darker hue, but do not burn.
Add the remaining chopped onion to the oil and sauté until translucent.
Add the blended pepper mix and cook until the sauce thickens and the oil rises to the top.
Add the assorted meat, locust beans, bouillon cubes, and salt. Cook for about 10 minutes.
Stir in the ground crayfish and simmer for an additional 5 minutes.
Serve with boiled eggs and fried plantains alongside white rice or ofada rice.

Ingredients:
2 cups ground egusi (melon seeds)
1 cup palm oil
2 cups washed and chopped Ugwu or bitter leaf
1 onion, chopped
3 tomatoes, blended
2 red bell peppers, blended
1 scotch bonnet pepper, blended
500g assorted meat and fish (beef, shrimp, and smoked fish)
2 bouillon cubes
Salt to taste
Water as needed
Procedures:
Heat the palm oil in a pot and fry the onions until translucent.
Add the blended tomatoes, bell peppers, and scotch bonnet. Cook until the oil separates from the mixture.
In a bowl make a thick paste of egusi and water, drop the paste like as balls in the stew and cook for about 5 minutes.
Bring to a boil
Add the assorted meat and fish, bouillon cubes, and salt. Simmer for 15 minutes.
Add the ugwu or bitter leaf, and cook for another 5 minutes or until the vegetables are tender.

Ingredients:
2 cups long-grain parboiled rice
1/4 cup vegetable oil
1 onion, chopped
1 can tomato paste (6 oz)
Water
1 bouillon cube
Salt to taste
Ground pepper 
Curry
Thyme
Procedures:
Rinse the rice under cold water and drain.
In a large pot, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat and fry the onion until translucent.
Stir in the tomato paste and cook for about till it is well fred then add the ground peppers and curry and thyme and add seasoning and cook 
When it boils add the rice, bouillon cube, salt, and enough water to cover the rice by about an inch and add some ring onions. 
Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer until the rice is cooked and the liquid is absorbed.
Fluff the rice with a fork before serving.

Ingredients:
2 cups rice, rinsed and drained
1/4 cup vegetable oil
1 large onion, finely chopped
1 teaspoon curry powder
4 cups water or chicken stock (if available)
1 bell pepper, chopped
2 seasoning cubes
2 cups mixed vegetables (such as carrots, peas, and corn)
Salt to taste
Procedures:
Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the onions and fry until translucent.
Stir in curry powder and let it cook for about a minute to release the flavors.
Add water or chicken stock and bring to a boil.
Stir in the chopped bell pepper.
Add the washed rice and crumble in the seasoning cubes. Reduce the heat, cover, and simmer until the rice is cooked and all the liquid is absorbed, about 18-20 minutes.
While the rice cooks, heat a little oil in a separate pan. Add the mixed vegetables and a pinch of salt. Cook until just tender.
Once the rice is cooked, fold in the seasoned vegetables.
Serve hot.

Ingredients:
4 cups cabbage, finely shredded
2 medium carrots, grated
1 cucumber, thinly sliced or julienned
3 tablespoons mayonnaise
1 tablespoon vinegar (optional, for a bit of tang)
Procedures:
In a large mixing bowl, combine the shredded cabbage, grated carrots, and sliced cucumber.
In a small bowl, whisk together the mayonnaise and vinegar if using. 
Pour the dressing over the vegetables and toss well to coat everything evenly.
Refrigerate the coleslaw for at least 30 minutes before serving to allow the flavors to meld together.
Serve chilled as a side dish.

Ingredients:
2 cups cabbage, shredded
1 head lettuce, chopped
1 cucumber, sliced
1 cup macaroni, cooked and cooled
2 carrots, grated or thinly sliced
1 cup sweetcorn, drained
1 can baked beans, drained and rinsed
1 can red kidney beans, drained and rinsed
1 cup green peas, cooked and cooled
2 hard-boiled eggs, sliced
Your preferred salad cream or mayonnaise
Procedures:
In a large salad bowl, layer the chopped lettuce and shredded cabbage as the base.
Scatter the sliced cucumber, grated carrots, and cooked macaroni evenly over the lettuce and cabbage.
Add the sweetcorn, baked beans, red kidney beans, and green peas to the salad.
Arrange the sliced hard-boiled eggs on top of the salad.
Drizzle your preferred salad cream or mayonnaise over the salad, or serve it on the side.
Toss all the ingredients together gently.

Ingredients:
4 slices of bread
2 eggs, beaten
1 can of sardines 
1 small onion, finely chopped
1 small tomato, chopped
Salt and pepper to taste
Butter
Procedures:
In a bowl, beat the eggs and season with salt and pepper. Mix in the mashed sardines, chopped onion, and tomato.
Butter one side of each bread slice.
Place two slices, buttered side down, on the toasting machine.
Spoon the sardine and egg mixture onto the non-buttered side of these slices.
Top with the remaining bread slices, buttered side up.
Close the toasting machine and toast until the bread is golden and crispy to your preference.
Serve hot

Ingredients:
4 slices of bread
2 eggs, beaten
1 cup cooked chicken, shredded
1 tablespoon mayonnaise
1 teaspoon mustard (optional)
1 small onion, finely chopped
Salt and pepper to taste
Butter
Procedures:
In a bowl, combine the beaten eggs, shredded chicken, mayonnaise, mustard, and chopped onion. Season with salt and pepper.
Butter one side of each bread slice.
Place two slices, buttered side down, on the toasting machine.
Spoon the chicken and egg mixture onto the non-buttered side of these slices.
Top with the remaining bread slices, buttered side up.
Close the toasting machine and toast until the bread is golden and crispy to your preference.
Serve hot and enjoy the creamy, flavorful chicken filling.

Ingredients:
4 slices of bread
4 eggs
Salt and pepper to taste
Butter
Procedures:
Beat the eggs in a bowl and season with salt and pepper.
Spread butter on each slice of bread on just one side 
Put the face buttered side of the bread on the toasting machine, add the mixed eggs on the non buttterd size and close with another bread with the buttered side facing up and toast till preffered crunchiness.
Serve hot.

Ingredients:
2 cups okra, grated or finely chopped
1 teaspoon sodium bicarbonate (Koun)
2 seasoning cubes (such as Maggi or Knorr)
Salt to taste
Procedures:
Wash the okra thoroughly. You can either grate it using a grater for a finer texture or chop it finely with a knife, depending on your preference.
In a pot, bring  water to a boil.
Add the grated or chopped okra to the boiling water 
Stir in the sodium bicarbonate (baking soda). This will help soften the okra and enhance its slimy texture, which is characteristic of many traditional West African okra soups.
Crumble the seasoning cubes into the pot and stir well to ensure they dissolve completely.
When the soup okra is almost soft, reduce the heat and let the soup simmer for about 10-15 minutes. This allows the flavors to meld together and the okra to cook thoroughly.
Serve hot with your choice of side such as fufu, pounded yam or eba

Ingredients:
500 grams goat meat, cut into bite-sized pieces
2 scotch bonnet peppers, finely chopped
1 onion, sliced
2 tablespoons vegetable oil
Salt to taste
Seasning cubes
Procedures:
Season and Grill the goat meat until almost tender.
In a pan, heat oil over medium heat, sauté the onions and scotch bonnets until soft.
Add the grilled goat meat to the pan, season with salt, and stir-fry until fully cooked and spicy.
Serve hot.

Ingredients:
2 cups palm oil
1 onion, finely chopped
2 tomatoes, blended
1 tablespoon tomato paste
1 scotch bonnet pepper, chopped
500 grams assorted meat (beef, tripe, chicken)
Salt to taste
Procedures:
Heat the palm oil in a pot, add the onion, and fry until golden.
Add the blended tomatoes, tomato paste, and scotch bonnet pepper, and cook until the oil separates from the sauce.
Add the assorted meat and enough water to cover the contents. Simmer until the meat is tender.
Season with salt and simmer for an additional 10 minutes.
Serve hot with rice or boiled yam.

Ingredients:
30-40 pieces Fresh Okra

1 Cooking spoon Palm oil

Assorted meats (Shaki, Ponmo, Cowfoot, Beef, Goat meat and Offals are ideal)

2-3 Pieces Stock fish

2 Medium size Smoked fish

Fresh prawns (Optional)

Smoked prawns

1 Cooking spoon Crayfish

2 Cups Chopped and washed Ugu leaves (substitute for Spinach, Water leaves or Kale)

Handful Uziza leaves, chopped and washed (Optional)

1 Onion

2-3 Scotch Bonnet (Ideally Yellow Nsukka Pepper)

Knorr Chicken Cubes/ Maggi Crayfish

Salt to taste
Procedures:
Pound in a mortar or chop the Okra with a processor. I prefer to chop 3/4 finely with a food processor then chop the rest by hand cos I love my Okra with a bit of crunch. If you want it chunky all through, with little or no elasticity, then you can chop the entire Okra. both ways is fine.Clean the Smoked Fish and soak in hot water to remove all traces of dirt, shred and set aside.Chop or blend the Scotch Bonnet and set aside. Also blend the Onion and set aside
Boil the meats, starting with tougher meats like Shaki, Cow foot, Ponmo, add softer meats as you go. Start by transferring the meats into a big pot, add blended Onions, Salt and Bouillon cubes, do not add water, allow the meats to sweat out. Stir from time to time and allow to steam for 5 minutes..After 5 minutes, add enough water to cook the meats, cover and cook till soft. When the meats are soft, add the Stockfish and leave to soften for 6-8 minutes..Then add chopped Pepper and half of the Crayfish…

Add the Smoked/ fresh Prawns, and shredded smoked Catfish, leave for 2 minutes….Add the Palm oil and leave to boil for 2-3 minutes. Use Palm oil sparingly, unlike Ila Alasepo, Otong soup requires very little palm oil..Now, add the Okra, combine and leave to cook for a minute…

Once the okra is added, do not cover the pot till you’re done cooking. covering will affect the elasticity of your Otong soup.Add the Ugu and Uziza leaves, combine and leave to cook for 2 minutes…

Add the rest of the Crayfish..Switch the heat off, then allow to simmer with the residual heat for 2 minutes…Your Otong Soup is ready! Enjoy with your preferred Swallow!

Ingredients:
Assorted meats (Beef, goat meat, Ponmo, Shaki are ideal)

2 Cooking Spoon Palm oil

1 Cup Bitter leaves (Fresh or Dried)

3-4 Medium Size Cocoyam (Ede)

2 Smoked Fish (Optional)

2-3 Stockfish (Optional)

3 Tablespoons Ground Crayfish

1 Tablespoon Ogiri Okpei

3 Tablespoons Ground Dry pepper or 2 Scotch Bonnet blended

2 Bouillon Cubes

Salt to taste
Procedures:
Start by boiling your meats, start with the tougher meats like Cow leg and Shaki first. When they’re slightly tender, add beef or other softer meats. When all the meats are tender, add the Stockfish, leave to cook till soft….
(Do not add Onions, Curry or Thyme!)                                                                                                                  While the meats are boiling, boil the Cocoyam with the skin on. Do not add salt, boil till tender, this should take roughly 20 minutes on medium heat…                                                                                                                   When they are soft, gently peel the skin off and pound till smooth in a mortar. Alternatively, chop them into small chunks and purée in your electric blender or food processor till smooth, then set aside…             Wash the Bitter leaves with hot water to get rid of as much bitterness as you can. There should be almost no hint of bitterness left in the leaves after washing.
(If you find yourself struggling to get rid of the bitterness, simply boil the leaves with enough water for 15 times, then rinse with cold water. )
If you’re using dried Bitter leaves, you’ll need to soak in warm water to plump it up and also get rid of dirt…When the Meats and Fish are all soft, add Crayfish, smoked Prawns, then add the ground or blended pepper. Stir and combine…                                                                                                                                               Add Palm oil, leave to thoroughly combine for 3-4 minutes….                                                                                Now, turn the heat done to low, add the blended Cocoyam into the stock in small dollops, be careful not to add too much. The consistency should be semi fluid….                                                                                    The Cocoyam will dissolve; thickening the soul, leave to dissolve and combine for 2-3 minutes.
(The thickness will depend on your preference. Ofe Onugbu is light and semi fluid though some role prefer it thick and creamy. I like mine Somewhat in between.)
Then add the Ogiri, stir and combine. Taste for seasoning and adjust if necessary…                                          Then add the washed Bitter Leaves, leave to cook for 2-3 minutes. Do not over cook your vegetables…     And it is ready , serve with your preferred swallow.

Ingredients:
Dough Ingredients:
500 Grams Plain Flour

1 Teaspoon Baking Powder

250 Grams Butter or Margarine

1/4 Cup Milk or Water

2 Medium Eggs

A Pinch of Salt

 

Filling ingredients:
300 Grams Minced Chicken OR

500 Grams Chicken With Bones (thigh, wings)

2 Medium Carrots Diced

2 Medium Irish Potatoes Diced

1 Medium Onion Diced

2 Cups Chicken Stock

100ml  Whole Milk or diluted evaporated milk

2 Heaped Tablespoons Plain Flour

1 Teaspoon Thyme

1 Tablespoon Curry Powder

1 Tablespoon Garlic Powder

I Tablespoon Chicken Seasoning of your choice

2 Knorr Chicken Cubes

Salt to Taste
Procedures:
Filling method:
Firstly, using a knife, make deep insertions on each chicken, this will allow the marinade to penetrate deep into the chicken. Marinate the chicken with 1/2 tablespoon curry, garlic powder, 1 knorr chicken and 1 teaspoon chicken seasoning. Place in a fridge and leave to marinate for at least 2 hours. Could be left overnight. The longer, the better.After it’s marinated to your satisfaction, transfer the chicken into a cooking pot, place on a hob on low heat add some chopped onions and salt to taste, leave to simmer for 15 minutes. Do not add water. This process allows the chicken to release its own juices.,stir occasionally….After 15 minutes, add 1-2 cups of water, taste for seasoning and adjust if necessary, let this slowly cook till tender…The chicken shouldn’t be too soft, just tender so it’s easy to shred as it will be cooked further with the carrots and potatoes…When it’s tender, take out the chicken and shred into small pieces…When the onions are fragrant, add the minced chicken if you’re using any, fry till the mince loses its pinkness….(Skip this step if you’re using just shredded chicken).Now add the shredded chicken, stir for a minute…..Now, add the carrots and potatoes. ..Also add 1 knorr cube, remaining garlic powder and curry powder, chicken seasoning, also add the thyme and salt to taste…
Mix thoroughly, when the potatoes and carrots start to cook, add the chicken stock and continue to cook till the potatoes and carrots are soft…
While this is cooking, mix the flour in 1 cup of water, mix till you get a smooth, milky consistency, set aside.
When the carrots and potatoes are soft, add the flour mixture, stir and combine, then add the milk…
Stir and combine really well…
Turn off the heat and leave to simmer with the residual heat for 3-5 minutes. Set aside.

Dough method:
Mix the flour, baking powder and salt together, sift to get rid of clumps…
Now add the butter, mix thoroughly till you get a crumbly/grainy texture…
Now add the milk or water gradually, you may not need to use the entire quantity so, add gradually…Nigerian chicken pie
Mix till you get a firm, non sticky dough, do not over work your dough…
When it’s done, wrap in cling film and leave to rest in a fridge for half an hour…
Crack the eggs into a bowl, mix and set aside…
Now take out the dough after half an hour, knead your dough…(you’ll notice the texture of the dough has changed, it should feel more manageable now)

Preheat your oven to 200 degrees Celsius….
Then get a rolling pin and roll the dough on a smooth surface, roll the dough into your desired shape, I’m using rectangles. Cut into desired size, scoop 2 tablespoons of the filling unto the rolled out dough…
Use a brush to gently rub the egg mixture on the edges of your dough…
Fold the dough over, use the back of a fork to firmly seal the dough…
Use the baking brush to gently glaze the top of the pie with the egg mixture…
Repeat the same process with the remaining dough and filling till they’re exhausted.
Place on a parchment paper lined or oiled/greased baking tray…nigerian chicken pie 4
Place in the preheated oven and bake for 30 minutes thereabouts or until the top begins to brown…

Ingredients:
Leftover rice
Egg yolks mixed into the rice
2-3 egg whites
Vegetable oil
1 cup mixed vegetables (e.g., carrots, peas, bell peppers)
Soy sauce to taste (or other seasoning if soy sauce isn’t available)
Procedures:
If not already done, mix the egg yolks into the cold leftover rice until well combined.
Heat some oil in a wok or large frying pan.
Fry the egg whites until just set, then remove and chop into small pieces.
In the same wok, add a bit more oil if needed.
Add the mixed vegetables and stir-fry until just tender.
Add the rice and egg yolks mixture to the wok.
Pour over soy sauce or your chosen seasoning, and stir-fry the rice until it’s crispy and heated through.
Add the chopped egg whites back into the wok.
Stir everything together well, ensuring the rice gets a nice crispy texture.
Serve hot, garnished with additional chopped spring onions or cilantro if desired.

Ingredients:
Onions (use more onions relative to other ingredients)
Ginger (use slightly less than the amount of onions)
Crayfish (use less than the amount of ginger)
Cooking oil
Maggi cubes (or any preferred seasoning cubes)
Salt to taste
Procedures:
Peel and roughly chop the onions and ginger.
Measure out the required amount of dried crayfish.
In a food processor or using a mortar and pestle, grind the onions, ginger, and crayfish together to form a coarse paste. The mixture should have more onions and ginger relative to the crayfish, creating a balanced blend of flavors.
Heat a generous amount of oil in a frying pan over medium heat. Once the oil is hot, carefully add the ground paste to the pan.
Season the paste with Maggi cubes and salt to taste.
Fry the mixture, stirring frequently to prevent it from sticking to the pan. Continue cooking until the paste turns a rich brown color, which indicates that the flavors have melded and intensified.
Once browned and aromatic, remove the paste from heat. This versatile paste can be served alongside a stew for waakye and rice&beans  .

Ingredients:
2 Cups Ofada Rice

Water

Salt to taste
Procedures:
Pick the stones and dirt from the Ofada rice. Do this carefully as Ofada rice is known to be very dirty and full of stones….
Pour the rice into a bowl, wash repeatedly.
Rinse till the water runs clean…
Now, add 4 Cups of water, allow to cook on low to medium heat for 12 minutes…
Do not cover the pot throughout!
Take the rice off the heat and rinse out the starch till water runs clean
Add 1 cup of water and cook till soft. You’ll need to check on it every now and then to prevent burning or sogginess. When it’s soft, take it off the heat and if you end up with liquid after the rice is fully cooked, drain in a colander…
Enjoy with Ofada Stew/ Ayamase…

Ingredients:
2 Cups Rice

4 cups Water

Salt to taste
Procedures:
Place the rice in a strainer and rinse under cold running water until the water runs clear. This helps to remove excess starch and improve the texture of the cooked rice.
In a medium pot, bring the water to a boil. Add the rinsed rice and salt.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and let the rice simmer for 18-20 minutes, or until all the water is absorbed and the rice is tender.
Remove from heat and let it sit, covered, for 5 minutes to allow the grains to settle and become fluffy.
Fluff the rice with a fork before serving. White rice can be served with a variety of dishes such as stews, sauces, and grilled meats or vegetables.

Ingredients:
2 cups beans (your choice of black-eyed peas or any preferred type), picked clean
1 large onion, chopped
Salt to taste
1 large yam, peeled and chopped into cubes
2 tablespoons grated pepper (such as scotch bonnet or your choice)
3 tablespoons palm oil
Procedures:
Rinse the beans thoroughly and place them in a large pot.
Add enough water to cover the beans by several inches.
Add the chopped onion and a pinch of salt to the pot.
Bring the water to a boil, then reduce the heat to a simmer. Cover and let the beans cook until they are almost soft, which may take about 1 to 1.5 hours depending on the type of beans.
When the beans are nearly done (soft but still firm), add the chopped yam to the pot.
Continue to cook on medium heat, allowing the yam to cook through, which should take about 20-30 minutes. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Once the yam is almost fully cooked, stir in the grated pepper and palm oil.
Add additional salt to taste.
Continue to cook the mixture for a few more minutes until the yam is completely soft and the flavors have melded together.
Serve hot as a hearty dish on its own or accompanied by a side of fried plantains or bread.

Ingredients:
3 ripe plantains, peeled and sliced
Enough vegetable stock or water to cover the plantains
1 onion, chopped
2 tomatoes, ground or blended
1 bell pepper, chopped
1 scotch bonnet pepper, finely chopped
200 grams smoked fish (Titus)
100 grams ponmo, prepared as above
2 tablespoons palm oil
Salt and bouillon cubes to taste
1 cup chopped ugwu leaves
Procedures:
Place the sliced plantains in a large pot and cover with vegetable stock or water.
Cook over medium heat until they are partly tender, about 10-15 minutes.
Cook the smoked fish and ponmo in a separate pot as described in the potato pottage recipe. Once cooked, chop into bite-sized pieces.
Add the chopped onions, ground tomatoes, bell pepper, and scotch bonnet to the plantains.
Continue cooking until the plantains are fully tender, about 10 more minutes.
Stir in the palm oil, smoked fish, and ponmo.
Lightly mash some of the plantains to thicken the pottage.
Season with salt and bouillon cubes to your taste.
Add the chopped ugwu leaves and simmer for another 5 minutes.
Mash the plantains to your preferred texture.
Serve hot, enjoying the sweet and savory flavors combined in this rich and satisfying dish.

Ingredients:
1/2 of a Small Yam

Vegetable oil

2 Ripe Plantains

1 Red, Yellow and Green Sweet Peppers

2Red Bell Peppers

1/2 Can Plum or 3 Medium Tomatoes

2 Onions

1 Scotch Bonnet

2 Bouillon Cubes

1 Teaspoon Curry Powder

1Teaspoon Dried Thyme

Salt to Taste
Procedures:
Blend the whole red bell peppers, tomatoes, scotch bonnet and one onion till smooth or semi smooth and set aside…
Chop the sweet peppers and one onion and set aside…
Chop the Yam into big size pieces, add 4-5 tablespoons of water, season with one Bouillon cube and set aside..
Clean and chop the Gizzard into bite size pieces, season with salt, one Bouillon cube, onions, Thyme and Curry powder, cook till soft..
When the Gizzard is well cooked, fry till golden brown…Chop the Plantain into bite size pieces, then fry till golden brown. Set aside.
I fry the Plantain and Gizzard in a deep fryer but I prefer to fry Yam on the hob for safety reasons, for Yam to properly cook, water has to be added to the oil. If/When  water is added to the oil, the water cooks the Yam before the frying process begins. To avoid any fire hazard,  I figure it’s safer to do this on a hob.
Now, place a saucepan on medium heat, then add vegetable oil. Make sure the heat isn’t too high. When it’s moderately hot, add the chopped Yam along with the water into the oil. Be careful when doing this cos you really don’t want to start a fire in your kitchen. Alternatively, you can remove the pan from the hob/fire before adding the Yam.
Fry till it’s well cooked. This should take 5-6 minutes. Leave to drain in a colander.
For the sauce, Pour 1.5 cooking spoon vegetable oil into a wok or deep pan, place on medium heat. When the oil is hot, add chopped onions, saute till translucent, then add the blended peppers, Thyme, curry powder, one Bouillon cube and salt to taste. Fry for 10-12 minutes. Be sure to stir every now and then to prevent burning..
After 10-13 minutes, add the chopped peppers and fry for a further 3 minutes…
Then, add the fried Gizzard, then the fried Yam, stir and combine. Leave to cook for 2 minutes…
Then, add the fried Plantain, cook for a minute. Don’t cook for too long to avoid the Plantain becoming soggy.
YamGizDodo is ready…

Ingredients:
4 slices of bread 
2 eggs
1/2 cup milk
2 tablespoons sugar
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon(optional)
Butter or oil for frying
Maple syrup and powdered sugar for serving
Procedures:
In a bowl, whisk together the eggs, milk, sugar, vanilla, and cinnamon.
Heat a skillet over medium heat and add a bit of butter or oil.
Dip each slice of bread into the egg mixture, allowing it to soak on both sides.
Fry the bread slices until golden brown on both sides, about 2-3 minutes per side.
Serve hot with syrup and a dusting of powdered sugar.

Ingredients:
1/2 pound water yam, peeled and grated
1 small onion, finely chopped
1-2 scotch bonnet peppers, finely chopped
Salt to taste
Oil for frying
Procedures:
In a bowl, mix the grated water yam, onion, scotch bonnet, and salt.
Heat oil in a deep fryer or a deep skillet.
Drop spoonfuls of the batter into the hot oil and fry until crisp and golden, about 5 minutes.
Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
Serve warm.

Ingredients:
For the Dough:

2 cups all-purpose flour
1/2 teaspoon salt
3/4 cup boiling water
For the Filling:

1 cup cooked chicken, finely chopped or shredded
1/2 cup spring onions, finely chopped
1 tablespoon soy sauce
1 teaspoon sesame oil
1 teaspoon ginger, grated
Salt and pepper to taste
Procedures:
In a mixing bowl, combine the flour and salt. Gradually add the boiling water, stirring with a fork or chopsticks until the mixture starts to come together.
Once cool enough to handle, knead the mixture on a lightly floured surface until smooth, about 10 minutes. Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
In a bowl, mix together the chopped chicken, spring onions, soy sauce, sesame oil, grated ginger, salt, and pepper.
Divide the rested dough into small balls, about 1 inch in diameter.
Roll each ball into a circle about 3 inches in diameter.
Place a small spoonful of the filling in the center of each dough circle.
Fold the dough over the filling to form a half-moon shape, pinching the edges to seal. Optionally, create pleats for a traditional look.
For Steamed Dumplings: Place the dumplings in a steamer lined with parchment paper or cabbage leaves. Steam over boiling water for about 15-20 minutes until the dough is tender.
For Soup Dumplings: Prepare a broth by bringing chicken broth to a simmer with additional spring onions and ginger slices. Drop the dumplings into the simmering broth and cook for about 15 minutes until they float and the dough is cooked through.

Serve the steamed dumplings hot with a dipping sauce made from equal parts soy sauce and vinegar, with a bit of chili oil if desired.
If serving soup dumplings, ladle some broth into bowls and add a few dumplings to each bowl.

Ingredients:
For the dough:
3 cups all-purpose flour
1/4 cup sugar
1 packet (2 1/4 teaspoons) instant yeast
1 cup warm milk
1/4 cup melted butter
1 teaspoon salt
For the filling:
3/4 cup brown sugar
2 tablespoons ground cinnamon
1/4 cup softened butter
Procedures:
Combine flour, sugar, yeast, warm milk, melted butter, and salt to form a dough. Knead until smooth.
Let the dough rise in a warm place until doubled in size, about 1 hour.
Roll out the dough into a rectangle. Spread softened butter over it, then sprinkle with brown sugar and cinnamon.
Roll up the dough and cut into slices. Place slices in a greased baking dish.
Let rise again until doubled. Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 25 minutes.
Optionally, drizzle with icing or cream cheese frosting before serving.

Ingredients:
Fish of your choice)
2 tablespoons olive oil
1 lemon, juiced
2 garlic cloves, minced
Salt and pepper to taste
Herbs and spices (like dill, paprika, or parsley)
Procedures:
Preheat your grill to medium-high heat.
In a small bowl, mix olive oil, lemon juice, garlic, salt, pepper, and any other herbs or spices you like.
Brush the mixture over both sides of the fish fillets.
Place fish on the grill and cook for about 3-4 minutes on each side, or until the fish flakes easily with a fork.
Serve hot with lemon wedges and a side of vegetables or salad.

Ingredients:
4 large potatoes, peeled and cubed
Enough vegetable stock or water to cover the potatoes
1 onion, chopped
2 tomatoes, ground or blended
1 bell pepper, chopped
1 scotch bonnet pepper, finely chopped (adjust based on your spice preference)
200 grams of smoked fish (e.g., mackerel, known as Titus in some regions)
100 grams of ponmo (cow skin), cleaned and cut into pieces
2 tablespoons palm oil
Salt and bouillon cubes to taste
1 cup ugwu leaves (pumpkin leaves), chopped
Procedures:
Place the cubed potatoes in a large pot and add enough vegetable stock or water to cover them.
Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer and let cook until they are partly tender, about 15 minutes.
In a separate pot, combine the smoked fish and ponmo with water. Season with a little salt and bouillon cube.
Cook over medium heat until they are both tender, about 15-20 minutes. Drain and chop into bite-sized pieces.
To the pot with the partly cooked potatoes, add the chopped onions, ground tomatoes, bell pepper, and scotch bonnet.
Continue cooking until the potatoes are completely tender, about 10 more minutes.
Add the palm oil, chopped smoked fish, and ponmo to the pot.
Lightly mash some of the potatoes in the pot to help thicken the pottage.
Season with salt and additional bouillon cubes to taste.
Stir in the ugwu leaves and simmer for another 5 minutes until the leaves are wilted and the flavors meld.
Mash the potatoes to your preferred texture.
Serve the pottage hot as a hearty and comforting meal.
